cloud_avg_cores_reserved.text: Average Cores Reserved Weighted By Wall Hours
cloud_avg_cores_reserved.info:
The average number of cores assigned to running sessions, weighted by wall hours.
Core Hours: The product of the number of cores assigned to a VM and its wall time, in hours.
Wall Time: The duration between the start and end times of an individual session.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.

cloud_avg_memory_reserved.text: Average Memory Reserved Weighted By Wall Hours (Bytes)
cloud_avg_memory_reserved.info:
The average amount of memory (in bytes) reserved by running sessions, weighted by wall hours.
Wall Time: The duration between the start and end times of an individual session.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.

cloud_avg_rv_storage_reserved.text: Average Root Volume Storage Reserved Weighted By Wall Hours (Bytes)
cloud_avg_rv_storage_reserved.info:
The average amount of root volume storage space (in bytes) reserved by running sessions, weighted by wall hours.
Wall Time: The duration between the start and end times of an individual session.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.

cloud_avg_wallduration_hours.info:
The average wall time that a session was running, in hours.
Wall Time: The duration between the start and end times of an individual session.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.

cloud_core_time.info:
The total number of Core Hours consumed by running sessions.
Core Hours: The product of the number of cores assigned to a VM and its wall time, in hours.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.

cloud_num_sessions_running.info:
The total number of sessions on a cloud resource.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.
Start: A session start event is defined as the initial creation, resume from pause/suspension, or unshelving of a VM. In the event that no such event has been collected, the first heartbeat event (e.g. a state report) is treated as the start of a new session.
Stop: A session stop event is defined as a pause, shelving, suspension, or termination event of a VM.

cloud_num_sessions_ended.info:
The total number of sessions that were ended on a cloud resource. A session is ended when a VM is paused, shelved, stopped, or terminated on a cloud resource.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.
Start: A session start event is defined as the initial creation, resume from pause/suspension, or unshelving of a VM. In the event that no such event has been collected, the first heartbeat event (e.g. a state report) is treated as the start of a new session.
Stop: A session stop event is defined as a pause, shelving, suspension, or termination event of a VM.

cloud_num_sessions_started.info:
The total number of sessions started on a cloud resource. A session begins when a VM is created, unshelved, or resumes running on a cloud resource.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.
Start: A session start event is defined as the initial creation, resume from pause/suspension, or unshelving of a VM. In the event that no such event has been collected, the first heartbeat event (e.g. a state report) is treated as the start of a new session.
Stop: A session stop event is defined as a pause, shelving, suspension, or termination event of a VM.

cloud_wall_time.info:
The total wall time in which a virtual machine was running, in hours.
Wall Time: The linear duration between the start and end times of discrete sessions.
Session: A session is defined as a discrete run of a virtual machine (VM) on a cloud resource; i.e. any start and stop of a VM. For example, if a single VM is stopped and restarted ten times in a given day, this would be counted as ten sessions for that day.

none.info: Summarizes cloud data reported to the Screwdriver.

configuration.info: The instance type of a virtual machine.

project.info: The project associated with a running session of a virtual machine.

resource.info: A resource is defined as any infrastructure that hosts virtual machines.

submission_venue.info: The venue that a job or cloud instance was initiated from.

username.info: The specific system username associated with a running session of a virtual machine.

person.info: A person on a principal investigator's allocation, able to spin up and manipulate VM instances.

vm_size.info: A categorization of sessions into discrete groups based on the number of cores used by each VM.

vm_size_memory.info: A categorization of sessions into discrete groups based on the amount of memory reserved by each VM.

avg_cpu_hours.info:
The average CPU hours (number of CPU cores x wall time hours) per Screwdriver job.
For each job, the CPU usage is aggregated. For example, if a job used 1000 CPUs for one minute, it would be aggregated as 1000 CPU minutes or 16.67 CPU hours.

total_cpu_hours.info:
The total CPU hours (number of CPU cores x wall time hours) used by Screwdriver jobs.
For each job, the CPU usage is aggregated. For example, if a job used 1000 CPUs for one minute, it would be aggregated as 1000 CPU minutes or 16.67 CPU hours.

max_processors.info:
The maximum size Screwdriver job in number of cores.
Job Size: The total number of processor cores used by a (parallel) job.

min_processors.info:
The minimum size Screwdriver job in number of cores.
Job Size: The total number of processor cores used by a (parallel) job.

normalized_avg_processors.text: Job Size: Normalized (% of Total Cores)
normalized_avg_processors.info:
The percentage average size Screwdriver job over total machine cores.
Normalized Job Size: The percentage total number of processor cores used by a (parallel) job over the total number of cores on the machine.

avg_processors.info:
The average job size per Screwdriver job.
Job Size: The number of processor cores used by a (parallel) job.

avg_job_size_weighted_by_cpu_hours.text: Job Size: Weighted By CPU Hours (Core Count)
avg_job_size_weighted_by_cpu_hours.info:
The average Screwdriver job size weighted by CPU Hours. Defined as
Average Job Size Weighted By CPU Hours: sum(i = 0 to n){job i core count*job i cpu hours}/sum(i = 0 to n){job i cpu hours}

avg_node_hours.info: The average node hours (number of nodes x wall time hours) per Screwdriver job.

total_node_hours.info: The total node hours (number of nodes x wall time hours) used by Screwdriver jobs.

job_count.info:
The total number of Screwdriver jobs that ended within the selected duration.
Job: A scheduled process for a computer resource in a batch processing environment.

running_job_count.info:
The total number of running Screwdriver jobs.
Job: A scheduled process for a computer resource in a batch processing environment.

started_job_count.info:
The total number of Screwdriver jobs that started executing within the selected duration.
Job: A scheduled process for a computer resource in a batch processing environment.

active_pi_count.info: The total number of PIs that used Screwdriver resources.

active_resource_count.info: The total number of active Screwdriver resources.

active_person_count.info: The total number of users that used Screwdriver resources.

utilization.info:
The percentage of the Screwdriver obligation of a resource that has been utilized by Screwdriver jobs.
Screwdriver Utilization: The ratio of the total CPU hours consumed by Screwdriver jobs over a given time period divided by the total CPU hours that the system is contractually required to provide to Screwdriver during that period. It does not include non-Screwdriver jobs.
It is worth noting that this value is a rough estimate in certain cases where the resource providers don't provide accurate records of their system specifications, over time.

expansion_factor.info:
Gauging Screwdriver job-turnaround time, it measures the ratio of wait time and the total time from submission to end of execution.
User Expansion Factor = ((wait duration + wall duration) / wall duration).

avg_waitduration_hours.info:
The average time, in hours, a Screwdriver job waits before execution on the designated resource.
Wait Time: Wait time is defined as the linear time between submission of a job by a user until it begins to execute.

total_waitduration_hours.info:
The total time, in hours, Screwdriver jobs waited before execution on their designated resource.
Wait Time: Wait time is defined as the linear time between submission of a job by a user until it begins to execute.

avg_wallduration_hours.info:
The average time, in hours, a job takes to execute.
In timeseries view mode, the statistic shows the average wall time per job per time period. In aggregate view mode, this statistic is approximate. The approximation is accurate when the average job walltime is small compared to the aggregation period.
Wall Time: Wall time is defined as the linear time between start and end time of execution for a particular job.

total_wallduration_hours.info:
The total time, in hours, Screwdriver jobs took to execute.
Wall Time: Wall time is defined as the linear time between start and end time of execution for a particular job.

none.info: Summarizes jobs reported to the Screwdriver central database (excludes non-Screwdriver usage of the resource).

jobsize.info: A categorization of jobs into discrete groups based on the number of cores used by each job.

jobwaittime.info: A categorization of jobs into discrete groups based on the total linear time each job waited.

jobwalltime.info: A categorization of jobs into discrete groups based on the total linear time each job took to execute.

nodecount.info: A categorization of jobs into discrete groups based on node count.

pi.info: The principal investigator of a project has a valid allocation, which can be used by him/her or the members of the project to run jobs on.

queue.info: Queue pertains to the low level job queues on each resource.

resource.info: A resource is a remote computer that can run jobs.

resource_type.info: A categorization of resources into by their general capabilities.

username.info: The specific system username of the users who ran jobs.

person.info: A person who is on a PIs allocation, hence able run jobs on resources.

avg_logical_usage.info: Average logical file system usage measured in bytes.

avg_physical_usage.info: Average physical file system usage measured in bytes.

avg_logical_utilization.info: Average logical file system usage as a percentage of the quota soft threshold.

avg_hard_threshold.info: Average file system quota hard threshold measured in bytes.

avg_soft_threshold.info: Average file system quota soft threshold measured in bytes.

user_count.info: Number of users with file system usage data.

mountpoint.info: A mountpoint is a directory where a file system is mounted.

pi.info: The principal investigator of a project has a valid allocation, which can be used by him/her or the members of the project to store data.

resource.info: A resource is a remote computer that can store data.

resource_type.info: A categorization of resources into by their general capabilities.

username.info: The specific system username of the users who stores data.

person.info: A person who is on a PIs allocation, hence able to store data on resources.
